Allen was distrusted by Dexter for all that he had been was England's first choice spinner and would take himself to the top of the England bowling averages as a result of this final Test. In any case it appeared that Dexter intended to catch Australia on a spinning wicket, especially if he batted first and caught them on the last day. <a href="Richie%20Benaud">Richie Benaud</a> was the <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20cricket%20team">New South Wales</a> captain and knew the <a href="Sydney%20Cricket%20Ground">Sydney Cricket Ground</a> better than anyone, but his bowling options were limited. <a href="Alan%20Keith%20Davidson">Alan Davidson</a> had recovered from his thigh strain and <a href="Garth%20McKenzie">Garth McKenzie</a> was showing great promise, but the medium-fast seam bowler <a href="Neil%20Hawke">Neil Hawke</a> was brought in to give them support and rest Davidson. <a href="Ken%20Mackay">Ken Mackay</a> was dropped in his favour, which weakened the Australian batting, but they still had nine first-class centurions. This left Benaud as Australia's sole specialist spinner, with help from <a href="Bob%20Simpson%20%28cricketer%29">Bobby Simpson</a> and perhaps <a href="Norm%20O%27Neill">Norm O'Neill</a>. <a href="Peter%20Burge%20%28cricketer%29">Peter Burge</a> had made 163, 34 not out, 33 and 54 not out for <a href="Southern%20Redbacks">South Australia</a> in the <a href="Sheffield%20Shield">Sheffield Shield</a> and was brought back into the team at the expense of <a href="Barry%20Shepherd">Barry Shepherd</a>. Dexter won the toss for the second time at Sydney, which had not helped him in the Third Test, and decided to bat.
England – First Innings.
By taking nine and a half hours to make their 321 on winning the toss England could point to the difficulty of forcing the ball away from so turgid a pitch and so dusty an in-field and finally across a slow, lush, green carpet. Naturally suspicious of player's alibis, I was very much on their side this time – up to a point.
With <a href="Geoff%20Pullar">Geoff Pullar</a> unable to play <a href="Colin%20Cowdrey">Colin Cowdrey</a> opened for England again, a role he did not relish and after making two runs he was out, mis-hitting a ball from <a href="Alan%20Keith%20Davidson">Alan Davidson</a> to <a href="Neil%20Harvey">Neil Harvey</a> at backward short-leg, who darted forward to take it at grass height. <a href="David%20Sheppard">David Sheppard</a> became <a href="Neil%20Hawke">Neil Hawke</a>'s first Test wicket, catching a full blooded cover drive off his own bowling. This made England 39/2 after 108 minutes and with <a href="Ken%20Barrington">Ken Barrington</a> entrenched at one end the crowd were looked to <a href="Ted%20Dexter">Ted Dexter</a> to produce some excitement. The wicket was dead and the sky was clear, so there was no chance of the ball swinging and the famous <a href="Sydney%20Cricket%20Ground">Sydney Hill</a> was becoming restless, Barrington raising his cap when he was jeered and a slow hand clap started around the ground as Dexter played himself in. This was briefly curtailed when Barrington glanced a <a href="full%20toss">full toss</a> from <a href="Garth%20McKenzie">Garth McKenzie</a> for four and Dexter hit three fours off <a href="Bob%20Simpson%20%28cricketer%29">Bobby Simpson</a>. <a href="Norm%20O%27Neill">Norm O'Neill</a> caught Barrington on the pads and appealed, but no else joined in and the Englishman stayed put. Australia were running through 14–15 overs an hour, the fastest so far in the series, but with such defensive play the effort was wasted. Dexter was out after lunch edging <a href="Norm%20O%27Neill">O'Neill</a> (1/38) to Simpson at first slip for 47 and <a href="Tom%20Graveney">Tom Graveney</a> almost went the same way to Benaud. At 5:15 pm the batsmen appealed for light, but were turned down and five minutes later he glanced McKenzie (1/57) off his legs, but "<a href="Neil%20Harvey">Harvey</a>, anticipating, shot out his left hand; he somersaulted and momentarily stood on his head, then he rolled over and sat up, still clutching the ball." Barrington usually woke up when his century was in sight, and a sweep of Simpson was dropped by <a href="Brian%20Booth">Brian Booth</a>, but a drive found its way to the boundary and a single brought up his hundred and a surprisingly generous round of applause from the stadium. He drove Benaud straight to Harvey in the covers, who bruised a finger taking his third catch, out for 101 after 320 minutes. <a href="Ray%20Illingworth">Ray Illingworth</a> and <a href="Fred%20Titmus">Fred Titmus</a> lasted until stumps, with England 195/5 after a full day's play. The second day continued in the same dull way, or perhaps worse as only three boundaries were hit between the two sides. Illingworth (27) and Titmus (34) produced, long, slow innings occasionally interrupted by drizzle before they were both caught by <a href="Wally%20Grout">Wally Grout</a>, one off Davidson and the other off Hawke (2/57). Even <a href="Fred%20Trueman">Fred Trueman</a> played a subdued innings before he was caught by Harvey off Benaud for 30. <a href="Alan%20Smith%20%28cricketer%29">Alan Smith</a> was bowled by Simpson (1/51) and <a href="David%20Allen%20%28cricketer%29">David Allen</a> and <a href="Brian%20Statham">Brian Statham</a> finally livened things up with a last wicket stand of 28 in 35 minutes until Benaud caught Allen off Davidson (3/43). England's 321 had taken them nine and a half hours, an innings more akin to saving a lost cause than trying to win a match.
Australia – First Innings.
The crowd of just on 30,000 was often tense during the fourth-wicket stand; <a href="Fred%20Titmus">Titmus</a> and <a href="David%20Allen%20%28cricketer%29">Allen</a>, pegging away, demanded concentration. But <a href="Norm%20O%27Neill">O’Neill</a> was determined not to be enchained.
Australia had less need than England to increase the scoring rate as a draw would save <a href="the%20Ashes">the Ashes</a>, but the burden of batting last meant that they should overhaul England's total by 50 runs because of the danger of being spun out on the last day. <a href="Bill%20Lawry">Bill Lawry</a> and <a href="Bob%20Simpson%20%28cricketer%29">Bobby Simpson</a> looked keen enough with 28 runs in the first half-hour even though <a href="Fred%20Trueman">Fred Trueman</a> hit Simpson on the shoulder with a beamer. He had Lawry caught behind for 12 and welcomed <a href="Brian%20Booth">Brian Booth</a> with a bouncer and a <a href="yorker">yorker</a> that nearly bowled him, followed by a <a href="leg%20before%20wicket">lbw</a> appeal from <a href="Brian%20Statham">Brian Statham</a>. After this it was the turn of the spinners <a href="Fred%20Titmus">Fred Titmus</a> and <a href="David%20Allen%20%28cricketer%29">David Allen</a> who bowled 90 over between them in the innings at a rate of 16–17 an hour and with great accuracy. Titmus bowled Booth in his second over, appealed for <a href="leg%20before%20wicket">leg before wicket</a> against <a href="Norm%20O%27Neill">Norm O'Neill</a> before he had scored and had Simpson caught by Trueman at leg-slip to give him 2/10 off 8 overs and to leave Australia 71/3. <a href="Neil%20Harvey">Neil Harvey</a> had been lowered down the order because of his bruise finger and <a href="Peter%20Burge%20%28cricketer%29">Peter Burge</a> came out for a few minutes before play ended at 5:38 pm. In the Sunday press conference <a href="Ted%20Dexter">Ted Dexter</a> thought that England would have a good chance of winning and that three days would be enough to force a win, a minority view. On the Monday morning O'Neill was full of confidence after his century at <a href="Adelaide">Adelaide</a> and refused to be tied town, or to submit to the flat wicket. He struck 6 fours in the morning session, and Burge 3, compared to the miserly 3 boundaries made on Saturday. He cause was helped by England's shoddy fielding, <a href="wicket-keeper">wicket-keeper</a> <a href="Alan%20Smith%20%28cricketer%29">Alan Smith</a> failed to stump O'Neill off Allen on 70 and dropped Burge off Statham on 63. O'Neill went after lunch, driving Allen into the outstretched hand of <a href="Tom%20Graveney">Tom Graveney</a> at short mid-on for 73, having added 109 with Burge. This brought <a href="Neil%20Harvey">Neil Harvey</a> to the crease in his farewell Test on his home ground to great applause and welcomed by the England team, as was <a href="Alan%20Keith%20Davidson">Alan Davidson</a>. Rain now interfered with play and there were two 20–25 minutes breaks, which upset his concentration, even so he added 51 with Burge before being caught by the substitute fielder <a href="Peter%20Parfitt">Peter Parfitt</a> off Statham (1/76) for 22, <a href="Colin%20Cowdrey">Colin Cowdrey</a> being off the field with an eye infection and Trueman was off with a strained thigh. Dexter (1/24) tried to bowl around the wicket to Davidson, who had tried to have the sightscreen moved over, only to find that it could not go that far to the left, so Dexter went back to bowling over the wicket, but the palaver had unsettled the batsman and he holed out to Allen. <a href="Richie%20Benaud">Richie Benaud</a> hit a Dexter bouncer to the boundary and dominated the strike for the last two overs to make 13 not out, leaving Burge on 98 and Australia 285/5, still 36 runs behind. Burge took four overs to reach his hundred the next morning, in slower time than Barrington, and was <a href="leg%20before%20wicket">lbw</a> trying to sweep Titmus for 103. <a href="Garth%20McKenzie">Garth McKenzie</a> was caught and bowled by Titmus, but <a href="Neil%20Hawke">Neil Hawke</a> hung on for an hour adding 44 with Benaud (57) before they were both caught by Graveney to give Titmus 5/103 off 47.2 overs and Allen 2/87 off 43 overs. The Australians were not riled so much by the crowd as the English batsmen had been, partly as O'Neill and Benaud had been making strokes, but also by the interest in seeing whether they could lead in the first innings. This they did, a total of 349 giving a slim lead of 28 runs.
England – Second Innings.
<a href="Ken%20Barrington">Barrington</a> had just missed his second century of the match, and in that he was unlucky, but his innings had been marred because on this last day he had added only 37 runs in 107 minutes. He had batted in all for 263 minutes, and his 94 runs included only two fours; but <a href="Richie%20Benaud">Benaud’s</a> defensive field-placing had contributed to that…<a href="Fred%20Trueman">Trueman</a> clouted <a href="Garth%20McKenzie">McKenzie’s</a> first two deliveries high to the fence, missed the third ball and was well caught by <a href="Neil%20Harvey">Harvey</a>, at mid-off, off the fourth. With the last ball of the last over before lunch, and inevitably his last ball in Test cricket…
England began their second innings after an early lunch taken on the fourth day, <a href="David%20Sheppard">David Sheppard</a> and <a href="Ray%20Illingworth">Ray Illingworth</a> making 40, the highest English first-wicket stand since the first Test. <a href="Alan%20Keith%20Davidson">Alan Davidson</a> bowled unchanged for two hours, bowling medium-paced cutters off a long run up to waste time. <a href="Garth%20McKenzie">Garth McKenzie</a> bowled one over and <a href="Neil%20Hawke">Neil Hawke</a> two before they were replaced by <a href="Richie%20Benaud">Richie Benaud</a>, bowling into a cold breeze which saw most of the crowd depart. Sheppard was dropped by a sleepy McKenzie at fine short-leg, where the excellent <a href="Norm%20O%27Neill">Norm O'Neill</a> had just been taken off with another throat infection. Benaud (3/71) took the first three wickets. Illingworth (18) driving the ball to Hawke in the covers, Sheppard (68), lifting the ball to <a href="Neil%20Harvey">Neil Harvey</a> for his fifth catch of the game and <a href="Ted%20Dexter">Ted Dexter</a> (6) who was stumped trying to hit his opposite number over the fence. <a href="Ken%20Barrington">Ken Barrington</a> had played a watchful innings from the other end, adding 97 with Sheppard, and <a href="Colin%20Cowdrey">Colin Cowdrey</a> ended the day at 165/3 after four hours, a lead of 137 over Australia with one day's play left. Quick runs were vital for setting up a victory – Dexter had vowed to declare at lunch come what may – and Cowdrey brought up his 50 with two boundaries and a three, but edged the new ball off Davidson to Benaud at second slip after making 53 in a stand of 94. Barrington touched a rising ball from McKenzie to <a href="Wally%20Grout">Wally Grout</a> for a 94 that contained only two fours. It was his fourth consecutive Test 50 and he would make 126 and 76 in New Zealand to equal the record of <a href="Patsy%20Hendren">Patsy Hendren</a> made in 1928–29 and <a href="Ted%20Dexter">Ted Dexter</a> at the beginning of the series. Davidson (3/80) picked up <a href="Tom%20Graveney">Tom Graveney</a> and <a href="Alan%20Smith%20%28cricketer%29">Alan Smith</a> and McKenzie (2/39) dismissed <a href="Fred%20Trueman">Fred Trueman</a> when he hit two fours and gave Harvey his sixth catch of the game with his last ball in Test cricket. Lunch was taken and Dexter declared, England had collapsed from 239/3 to 268/8 and this gave his bowlers four hours to take 10 wickets for 240 runs.
Australia – Second Innings.
The crowd booed, barracked and slow-clapped but the Australians refused to try for a result. It was disappointing but, somehow, inevitable. Winning or losing <a href="the%20Ashes">the Ashes</a> was even then such a huge event that no captain wanted to take unnecessary risks.
<a href="Richie%20Benaud">Richie Benaud</a> may have been prepared to go for the runs, but <a href="Fred%20Trueman">Fred Trueman</a> (1/6) bowled <a href="Bob%20Simpson%20%28cricketer%29">Bobby Simpson</a> with his fifth ball and <a href="Bill%20Lawry">Bill Lawry</a> dug himself in to make 18 not out in the two hours between lunch and tea. <a href="Neil%20Harvey">Neil Harvey</a> came in at number three, but struggled to 28 when he was bowled by well flighted ball from <a href="David%20Allen%20%28cricketer%29">David Allen</a>. <a href="Norm%20O%27Neill">Norm O'Neill</a> took 17 minutes to open his score, cut two fours off <a href="Ken%20Barrington">Ken Barrington</a> and another off <a href="Fred%20Titmus">Fred Titmus</a> until he tried to force a ball down the off-side and was caught by <a href="Alan%20Smith%20%28cricketer%29">Alan Smith</a> off Allen, who then bowled <a href="Brian%20Booth">Brian Booth</a> with a shooter for a duck and Australia went into tea at 75/4 with Allen on 3/23. During tea Benaud told Lawry and Burge to "stay in" and they needed little encouragement to do so. Lawry dragged out his innings to 45 not out in four hours regardless of cat-calls, hoots, jeers and the rattling of beer-cans. At one point, Lawry hit two fours in succession, prompting the crowd to yell "lightning does strike twice!" Burge at least hit the bad balls and made 52 not out when time was called. They have saved a potential disaster for Australia, but were booed off when they left the field on 152/4 and their actions – as ordered by their captain – won them few friends and was bad for Australian cricket.
Result.
If there had been no Ashes and £1,000 a man for winning today's game, I daresay there would have been a result. the fact that these matches are played in a series is a damper. The fact that <a href="the%20Ashes">the Ashes</a> must be fought for is a further damper. I believe that if a series is drawn, then <a href="the%20Ashes">the Ashes</a> should at least go into <a href="Pawnbroker">pawn</a> so that no one holds them.
I am extremely disappointed with the overall picture of Test play, which was not the kind of cricket I want to watch. People who pay to see a Test are entitled to see a real match, not a tactical tie-up. I think it is a fair result that neither England or Australia won the series. I can't get out of my head why Test matches are so different from State matches, where I think England played pretty well. It is all so different from what we visualised. After all this talk of brighter cricket I think we should get back to playing cricket. Perhaps a little more action and less talk.
The Fifth Test was drawn and Australia retained <a href="the%20Ashes">the Ashes</a> by sharing the series 1–1. Both captained were criticised by the press and public for such a dismal ending to the series and the reputations of <a href="Richie%20Benaud">Richie Benaud</a> and <a href="Ted%20Dexter">Ted Dexter</a> as attacking captains were badly tarnished. <a href="Brian%20Statham">Brian Statham</a> ended the series with a record 242 Test wickets, with <a href="Alec%20Bedser">Alec Bedser</a>, <a href="Fred%20Trueman">Fred Trueman</a> and <a href="Richie%20Benaud">Richie Benaud</a> tied on 236. Statham did not tour New Zealand, but Trueman did and he overtook his new ball partner to become the first man to take 250 Test wickets. <a href="Ted%20Dexter">Ted Dexter</a> made 481 runs (48.10), the most by an <a href="List%20of%20England%20cricket%20captains">England captain</a> in Australia, beating <a href="Archie%20MacLaren">Archie MacLaren</a>'s 412 runs (45.77) made in <a href="English%20cricket%20team%20in%20Australia%20in%201901-02">1901–02</a>, a total that has yet to be exceeded. <a href="Ken%20Barrington">Ken Barrington</a> made 582 runs (72.75), the most by an Englishman in Australia since <a href="Wally%20Hammond">Wally Hammond</a>'s 905 runs (113.12) in <a href="English%20cricket%20team%20in%20Australia%20in%201928-29">1928–29</a>.
1962–63 Test Series Averages.
<a href="https%3A//cricketarchive.com/Archive/Events/AUS/Marylebone_Cricket_Club_in_Australia_and_New_Zealand_1962-63/Team_Averages.html">source</a> This was the last tour to use the old divisions of <a href="Gentlemen%20v%20Players">amateurs and professionals</a> in English cricket so the convention remained of gentleman amateurs having their initials in front of their surname and professional players with their initials after their name, if used at all. The Australians all remained amateurs until the <a href="Kerry%20Packer">Packer Revolution</a>, even though they played like professionals.
